articles.headline: A Global Boom, but Only for Some
articles.snippet: Globalization improved the lot of hundreds of millions of people in the developing world, but not — as its promoters promised — the living standards of most American workers.
articles.abstract: Globalization improved the lot of hundreds of millions of people in the developing world, but not — as its promoters promised — the living standards of most American workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember when Al Gore took on H. Ross Perot? It was November 1993. Mr. Gore deployed his smoothest scorn to swat down the cantankerous billionaire’s argument that the North American Free Trade Agreement would produce a “great sucking sound” of jobs flowing to Mexico. The agreement, Mr. Gore said, would become an engine of American prosperity.

articles.headline: New Social App Has Juicy Posts, All Anonymous
articles.snippet: Posts on Secret, an app that allows users to upload anonymous messages, can range from benign to inappropriate and are testing the tech industry’s appetite for sharing.
articles.abstract: Posts on Secret, an app that allows users to upload anonymous messages, can range from benign to inappropriate and are testing the tech industry’s appetite for sharing.
articles.lead_paragraph: From Facebook to Twitter to Instagram and Google, many big Internet successes depend on coaxing people into sharing every last bit of information about themselves and their lives.

articles.headline: Costly Loans Are Drawing Attention From States
articles.snippet: States are increasing efforts to shield vulnerable Americans from short-term loans with interest rates that can exceed 300 percent.
articles.abstract: States are increasing efforts to shield vulnerable Americans from short-term loans with interest rates that can exceed 300 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Loralty Harden, a 62-year-old retiree, was distressed when the balance on a short-term loan she had obtained to supplement her Social Security income did not budge even though she diligently followed the payment plan that came with it.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: If Not a Cold War, a Return to a Chilly Rivalry
articles.snippet: Tensions over Crimea may not bring a new Cold War, but analysts worry about a long period of confrontation and alienation.
articles.abstract: Tensions over Crimea may not bring a new Cold War, but analysts worry about a long period of confrontation and alienation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A month ago, most Americans could not have found Crimea on a map. But its lightning-quick takeover by Moscow has abruptly redrawn the geopolitical atlas and may have decisively ended a 25-year period of often tumultuous yet also constructive relations between the United States and Russia.

articles.headline: New Alliances in Battle for Corporate Control
articles.snippet: The abrupt rise and increasing success of activist investors are forcing big money managers to reassess their traditionally passive role as shareholders.
articles.abstract: The abrupt rise and increasing success of activist investors are forcing big money managers to reassess their traditionally passive role as shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: For ages, institutional investors like mutual funds and pension funds were content to take stakes in public companies, trust their managements and bet on long-term gains. Companies trusted that these investors would be passive shareholders and not rock the boat.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Toyota Expected to Settle Justice Dept. Investigation
articles.snippet: Toyota is poised to pay more than $1 billion to settle a criminal investigation into disclosures around the sudden acceleration of its vehicles.
articles.abstract: Toyota is poised to pay more than $1 billion to settle a criminal investigation into disclosures around the sudden acceleration of its vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toyota is poised to pay more than $1 billion to settle a criminal investigation into disclosures around the sudden acceleration of its vehicles, a steep fine that caps a multiyear inquiry and provides a template for the authorities pursuing a similar case against General Motors.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Toyota Is Fined $1.2 Billion for Concealing Safety Defects
articles.snippet: A deal with the Justice Department over a sudden-acceleration defect that has caused injuries and deaths included an unusual admission of wrongdoing.
articles.abstract: A deal with the Justice Department over a sudden-acceleration defect that has caused injuries and deaths included an unusual admission of wrongdoing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eric H. Holder Jr., the United States attorney general, talked in impassioned tones on Wednesday about Toyota’s behavior in hiding safety defects from the public, calling it “shameful” and a “blatant disregard” for the law. A $1.2 billion criminal penalty, the largest ever for a carmaker in the United States, was imposed.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Matt Apuzzo
